nit: i think line 68-70 can be removed (to avoid confusion), looks like abandoned legacy code:
```
kwargs = {}
if self.delegate_to:	      
    kwargs['sub'] = self.delegate_to
```
thanks for fixing this!
Updated PR. Instead of killing gunicorn actually using pidfile, it uses mock.patch to emulate the situation that gunicorn doesn't respond. @Fokko would you take a look?

@jgao54 Any updates on this?
@NielsZeilemaker PTAL

Hello @dimberman, I'm very keen to start testing this on one of our clusters. I can see that there's a YAML manifest in the repo - however is there a Docker image publicly available which we can use that has this executor built into it?

Also, is there a way to use this executor so that each individual DAG task can be run in a separate container pod with a different image? I have a run of DAGs that have varying dependencies that I currently separate out with venvs, but with Kubernetes, I was looking to separate out the tasks by Docker images instead.

I also feel that this and the postgres database should be deployed with Helm instead of static manifest files. There is a work-in-progress Helm chart at:

- https://github.com/kubernetes/charts/pull/3959/

Another thing, should this be using the Jobs specification for the containers running the tasks instead of the Pod one?

- https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/workloads/controllers/jobs-run-to-completion/

@sebradloff funny you should mention it, I was writing a small blog post about how to enable this & just finished wrapping it up - http://agrajmangal.in/blog/big-data/mesos-airflow-docker/ Feel free to suggest changes and/or improvements
LGTM
cc @Fokko

@ashb Want to try merging this one?
@NielsZeilemaker and @Fokko I think this PR can close this issue too: [AIRFLOW-1775 - Remote file handler for logging](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-1775)
I don't agree, an azure fileshare is something different than a blob store
Hi @NielsZeilemaker indeed. I was thinking about a workaround (using the blob store and not the azure fileshare), but reading it again I think you're right. Sorry.

@ashb Did you merge using the airflow-pr tool or manually merge? If you use the tool, the commit will say "authored by tmccartan and Ash Berlin-taylor committed...". If you manually, merge, I believe it actually creates a commit in your name, which is what I see in the commit log. Any issues running the tool? I ask as I am currently running into some TLS issue running the tool and wonder if it's broken for others as well.

I did merge with the tool, yes. I chose no to squash on this (as it was only one commit).

The Jira issue bit failed because I didn't (at the time) have the Jira python module installed.

Hmn.. I usually don't squash either. I wonder what's different. Usually, the "authored.... committed" line is preferable as it doesn't create extraneous merge commits and uses the "rebase and merge" option in github (i believe). The way it seems to have gone for you is not that route, but merge (which looks the same for single-commit PRs as a squash and merge.)

To me a generic SAML integration, or a generic OAuth/OpenID Connect authentication method makes more sense than dealing with Okta's API directly. The Okta API tokens are a bit dangerous access-wise. Airflow also already has GitHub and Google OAuth integrations, and Okta supports OpenID & OAuth, so that might be the most natural thing to add.

https://airflow.apache.org/security.html#oauth-authentication
lgtm (especially since no existing tests break)

Hi @jpds 

1. There's no official docker image yet, however you can currently run docker build on scripts/ci/kubernetes/docker/Dockerfile to build the image. Once the PR is merged I think it would be good to discuss where that official docker image would live.

2. Yes actually! That is one of the main features we are releasing with this new executor :). please check the `example_kubernetes_executor.py` file to see an example of running with a custom docker container.

3. The deployment currently in the code-base is for the travis tests so it doesn't really require a custom deployment. I think integrating it with helm is a great idea.

4. The pods vs. jobs discussion has gone on for a while. The problem is that jobs will run repeatedly until they pass. This could be potentially disastrous in the context of an airflow job (imagine you have a script that launches a spark job that keeps failing).

@Fokko @bolkedebruin apologies that there has been some delay on the final steps. I was waiting for https://github.com/bloomberg/airflow/pull/44 to be rebased so I could merge it before we merge, but I think this can wait and we can PR against master once the main PR is merged. I will do the final rebases and clean up requested so we can start the alpha testing.

@agrajm Love the post! 

To deal with the Mesos python eggs issue, we've built an upstream docker image for the version of Mesos we use (1.4.0) and then simply use the docker multi stage build to copy over those eggs from that image. We plan on getting that together and releasing the pattern within the next 2 weeks once we've got the MesosExecutor running.

Regarding the `docker_image_slave` setting, it would be really cool if we could also specify memory and CPU constraints on a per Operator or DAG basis so that we're optimizing our resources to the fullest. Correct me if I'm wrong, this is my interpretation based on the source code. Full disclosure we haven't run the MesosExecutor yet but just confirmed running the LocalExecutor in a deployed environment with s3 remote logs and external psql metadabase.

Totally understand the need to specify docker as a containerizer for Mesos agents, but what's the reasoning behind needing `mesos` listed as a conatinerizer? Reading [the docs](http://mesos.apache.org/documentation/latest/containerizers/)  I'm not sure I follow how specifically the Airflow MesosExecutor setup would require the `mesos` containerizer assuming Docker provides all the control you would need.

I think an amazing addition to that post would be an architecture diagram of what all this looks like. I took a shot at it here: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1sfbZ7W14BeYvqoOCupvB8vADuDQY1Xmt/view Basically something that gives a picture of the architecture that you need to standup and making it clear that tasks are spun up dynamically in containers.

Please lmk if there's anything else I can help with. Really want this to succeed and help make this all easier to understand for those that come along. Overall, I can feel the shift of infrastructure people being tasked with operationalizing airflow in more than just "one massive EC2 instance". Anything we can do to make this workflow more easily understood will be a win for data scientists and infrastructure teams.
@dan-sf Please fix your line endings. Now the full file is marked as a diff. Cheers
@ashb Nice work

I squash most of the time. By squashing it, it will amend the commit, and generate a new commit hash. Because the hashes don't match up, the PR in Github appears to be closed instead of merged. Apparently the author was reset on the commit. Something went wrong, because I would expect having the commit under the name of the original author.

Let me check if I can figure out what's happening

So I'm able to replicate it on my local machine:
```
[2018-03-07 12:16:30,529] {jobs.py:2592} WARNING - State of this instance has been externally set to None. Taking the poison pill.
```
So I suspect that somewhere in the code, the TaskInstance is upserted with the failed state.

This makes sense: https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/commit/db816ee6883ae0585ec8b0b149274c1ed6ec0d8e The test is from two years back: https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/commit/7c0f8373f59b0554d5ba15bb0e5e8669f0830313 And the ticket: https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/AIRFLOW/issues/AIRFLOW-234

Personally I have the strong suspicon that the:
```
ti = session.query(TI).filter_by(
    dag_id=task.dag_id,
    task_id=task.task_id,
    execution_date=DEFAULT_DATE
).one()
```

Query returns more than one result, and therefore fetches a TI with state `FAILED`. @mistercrunch Any thoughts on this?

I can't think of a situation where the the `task_instance` records would be deleted from the database.

@dimberman Another thing which I require to be able to set with this is pod affinity[1] for a particular task.

On AWS, I have some rather compute intense tasks which need to land on large EC2 instances separate from our main cluster instances. We do this normally with this for example:

```
spec:
  affinity:
    nodeAffinity:
      requiredDuringSchedulingIgnoredDuringExecution:
        nodeSelectorTerms:
        - matchExpressions:
          - key: beta.kubernetes.io/instance-type
            operator: In
            values:
            - c5.9xlarge
```
Mind rebasing on master to fix the tests?

Could use `Flask-OAuthlib` to create a mock OAuth2 server for all of the OAuth2 related auth backends, special casing for any quirks they have.

But if you wanted to actually test with Google OAuth2, that's a much more involved process that would probably require a headless browser and a GCP account. I'm not sure what the process would be with GHE, but given you need a license to run it I'm not sure it would be much easier.

Could testing this be added as a separate Jira ticket since it's non-trivial?
It 100% works with GCP for us, but since I can't test with GHE I can remove that part of the change, unless someone else can test it.
